messages: c84247cefeb3a07c65c26753231e17f7 (06:56): Meriwether: i have solaris 1.1.3 media
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:17): Auralis: I think I do too, actually.  Er, 1.0, not 1.1.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:18): Auralis: Do you have intel OpenSTEP media?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:18): I've also got SunOS 4.1.4 media which converts to some Solaris 1.x release.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:18): delewis: Mine won't boot in VMWare.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:18): mine'll boot, but the device support isn't too good.
c84247cefeb3a07c65c26753231e17f7 (07:18): nope, ever wanted it, never found it
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:18): even OpenSTEP 4.2
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:18): you have to do quite a bit of work to get it working.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:19): haven't tried 5.x
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:19): (5.x has a new VESA driver that I'm fairly sure OpenSTEP doesn't like)
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:20): I could use an image of that.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:20): but most of the information I got was from the online VMware/OpenSTEP howtos.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:20): My OpenSTEP is about 5 years old.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:20): And it just doesn't even boot.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:21): I've still got the media, but I'll need to find it, rip it, and throw it on my HTTP server
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:21): want the Developer Tools, too?
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:21): Yes, definitely.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:23): That would be very rulin.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:23): I recently stumbled on the fact that SIMH will run UNIX V7.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:24): So I have got on my old OS kick again.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:24): I'd like to get OpenSTEP, SCO, and VMS/VAX running.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:26): This is the 4th time my wife has gone to the bathroom in an hour.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:26): I'm starting to worry.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:28): well, I'm ripping the 4.2 user and developer ISOs, now -- once they're ripped, I'll /msg you with a link so that you can download 'em.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:28): I suppose you're not interested in MSDOS6 source, either? :-)
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:28): I've got a 100MB .zip file of it.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:30): I'm not sure what I'd do with it.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:30): Have you peeked at it?
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:30): What's it look like?
7ef291c89ad915978b203d427919cfbb (07:30): i watched  freedos boot on my blade 1500 last week does that count?
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:31): Meriwether: 99% x86 assembly and 1% Qbasic for the QBasic demos.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:31): I had one semester of assembly.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:31): and you can gather from the build documentation that Microsoft rolled out builds on OS/2 systems.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:31): Which is more than I really needed.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:31): or rather they had the source stored on OS/2 and possibly built the source using OS/2 systems.
53303ac79660a60ff15ef2ae2835996f (07:32): it's actually quite a lot of source, though. a 100MB .zip file, which decompresses to about 200MB, IIRC.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:33): That would be about 50M of C, and 10M of Perl.
24340ef160b44f4e9d826263c6dd3188 (07:33): Were you to implement DOS in Perl.
